References.Title: The effect of intra-class ability grouping on arithmetic achievement in grades two through five.
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of intra-class ability grouping on arithmetic achievement. The specific objectives were:(1) to compare on each school grade level the arithmetic achievement of pupils taught in intra class groups with those taught in the traditional" class-as-a-whole" manner,(2) to compare achievement in computation, in problem solving, and in arithmetic average between each intra-class group and comparable sets of pupils in the control classes. The arithmetic sections of the Stanford Achievement Test, Form M, were administered during the eighteenth week of the semester; pupil grade placements were compiled and studied for comparative gains in problem solving, computation, and arithmetic average. Grade-placement gains for intra -class groups and their matched partners in control classrooms were compared. The 't'- test was used to test for significant differences in gains. The five per cent level of significance was used to reject the hypothesis that no significant differences in the gains existed. The results indicated that the experimental classes achieved significantly higher gains than did the control classes in the following: arithmetic average, Grade Two, Grade Four and Grade Five; computation , Grade Two, Grade, Four, and Grade Five; and problem solving Grade Two. On the basis of the evidence presented in this study, it is indicated that intra-class ability grouping is a procedure which may be used to improve arithmetic achievement in Grades Two through Five of the elementary school.
References.Comments: This study provides findings for 4 different grades and 3 different outcomes. Please focus in coding arithmetic and computation ignoring problem solving outcome. Please code mean gain data for grade 5 with arithmetic as the primary outcome and computation as the secondary for test 1 and 2 combined.
References.QuickCitation: Smith WM (1960) The effect of intra-class ability grouping on arithmetic achievement in grades two through five.. New Orleans: ,

References.Title: Effects of Ability Grouping on Growth in Academic Achievement
References.Abstract: This paper applies a theory of growth in academic achievement to the study of the effects of ability grouping on reading achievement. The theory sees students ability and effort determining how they utilize opportunities for learning provided by instruction. The mathematical specification of the theory allows for the estimation of models that show (a) ability grouping provides fewer opportunities for learning than whole class instruction but greater utilization of those opportunities; (b) high ability groups provide more opportunities than low groups; and (c) small homogeneous groups facilitate reading achievement more than larger, more heterogeneous groups.
References.Comments: This study has multiple groups and models. Please focus in coding data on table III model 3.1. v.s 3.2.
References.Authors: Srensen Aage B; Hallinan Maureen T;
References.QuickCitation: Srensen Aage B, and Hallinan Maureen T (1986) Effects of Ability Grouping on Growth in Academic Achievement. American Educational Research Journal 23(4), 519-542 DOI: https://doi.org/10.3102/00028312023004519

References.Title: An Eight Year Study of Classes Grouped Within Grade Levels on the Bases of Reading Ability
References.Abstract: This was a study of children grouped homogeneously on the basis of reading ability into classes within a grade. It has encompassed six experimental years, a transition pilot year, and a control year. All Marshfield children enrolled in grades one through six during the years 1953-1954 through 1960-1961 have been included in this study. Hereafter this will be referred to as the Marshfield Plan of Grouping. The study was conducted to determine whether selective grouping on the basis of reading has improved reading achievement and general achievement. The academic progress for the total grade population was evaluated. Evaluation was also conducted to determine the academic effect of the grouping on the children in the upper third, middle third and lower third of each grade when the total group was divided on the basis of the I.Q. scores. Since this was a longevity study where homogeneous grouping of classes within each grade had been carried out for eight years in one school and one town, it was considered important to determine whether learning had been affected positively or negatively and also whether there had been a consistent pattern of growth. In general, during the eight years of the study, there was a consistent and significant linear trend both in general achievement and reading achievement for the total population.

References.Title: An evaluation of an elementary school enriched instructional program
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evaluate some of the educational outcomes of an experimental enriched instructional program. Four areas of investigation were established: general academic achievement, work study skills, critical thinking, and leadership development. The analysis of the data revealed that the general findings support the belief pupils enrolled in the enriched instructional program would demonstrate significantly greater achievements than pupils enrolled in the regular instructional program, The achievements of experimental groups in the reading, language, arithmetic, and science areas were most pronounced. Some evidence was available to suggest that the experimental group also achieved better than the controls in the work-study skills achievement area. Available data did not Support the critical thinking hypothesis. Pupils from the enriched instructional program groups surpassed their matched counterparts with regard to participation and leadership in school related activities.
